heading: 1.1.7 Vectors
text:
Vectors univariate data structures. Vectors can created using c() function 
elements separated commas.Note examplevar1 actually vector length 1.calling vectors Console, note numbers square brackets

heading: 1.1.7.1 Extracting elements
text:
elements vectors can extracted supplying vector positive integers inside square

heading: 1.1.8 Data frames
text:
Data frames multivariate data structures. Data frames can thought vertical
concatentation vectors. cases, column data frame contains values 
single variable row data frame contains values variable single
observation. example, consider following data set:example , column contains values single variable row contains
values variable single observation (patient).Things note:Data frames can created supplying name-value pairs data.frame() function.Name-value pairs supplied using = rather <-.name-value pair must length. Missing values can represented using NA.
code:
patients <- data.frame(
  patient_id = c("123abc", "28fnr8", "02jr8d", "r82j45", "t90ro5"),
  height = c(181, 145, 190, 210, 94),
  mass = c(85, 72, 82, 90, 60),
  sex = c("M", "F", "M", "F", "F")
)

patients##   patient_id height mass sex
## 1     123abc    181   85   M
## 2     28fnr8    145   72   F
## 3     02jr8d    190   82   M
## 4     r82j45    210   90   F
## 5     t90ro5     94   60   F

heading: 1.1.8.1 Extracting columns
text: Columns data frame can extracted vectors using dollar sign ($).

heading: 1.1.8.2 Extracting rows and subsets
text:
Thinking data frames matrices, can subsetted supplying row column
positions/names separated comma within square brackets:
code:
# Extract row 3 and all columns
patients[3, ]##   patient_id height mass sex
## 3     02jr8d    190   82   M
# Extract rows 1, 4, and 5, and columns 1 and 3
patients[c(1, 4, 5), c(1, 3)]##   patient_id mass
## 1     123abc   85
## 4     r82j45   90
## 5     t90ro5   60
# Extract rows 1, 4, and 5, and columns "patient_id" and "mass"
patients[c(1, 4, 5), c("patient_id", "mass")]##   patient_id mass
## 1     123abc   85
## 4     r82j45   90
## 5     t90ro5   60
# Extract everything *except* rows 2 and 3, and columns 2 and 3
patients[-c(2, 3), -c(2, 3)]##   patient_id sex
## 1     123abc   M
## 4     r82j45   F
## 5     t90ro5   F

heading: 1.1.10 Paths
text:
path string (.e. needs surrounded quotes) describes location file 
folder device. Paths become extremely important reading writing files R. Paths
can broken two categories: absolute relative.

heading: 1.1.10.1 Absolute paths
text:
absolute path gives full location file/folder device, irrespective 
current working directory, e.g.use absolute paths creates problems.Suppose Windows include path like "C:/Users/Adam/Desktop/blah.R" 
script. execute code given Windows machine, likely
work since name probably Adam blah.R may located Desktop
like mine.Suppose Windows include path like "C:/Users/Adam/Desktop/blah.R" 
script. execute code given Windows machine, likely
work since name probably Adam blah.R may located Desktop
like mine.users Windows, addition folders possibly existing, likely
"C drive".users Windows, addition folders possibly existing, likely
"C drive"., use absolute paths recommended complicates sharing code
devices platform-dependent.

heading: 1.1.10.2 Relative paths
text:
relative path gives partial location file/folder relative working directory.
Although use relative paths still assumes identical partial folder structure, 
assume identical folder structure root path.two helpers specifying relative paths: dot, ".", double-dot, "..". 
dot, ".", can thought shorthand "", current working directory. 
double-dot, "..", means "go one level".Example 1:Suppose working directory "C:/Users/Adam/Desktop" structure:Inside script1.R, want read data found my_data.txt. can done using:rather using:Example 2:Suppose working directory "C:/Users/Adam/Desktop/model" surrounding folder
structure:Inside model.R, want read data found my_data.txt. can done using:rather using:

└── other.R

heading: 1.2.3 Fitting the SLR model
text:
Linear regression models fit using lm() function. first need fit model\[Y_{} \,=\, \beta_{0} \,+\, \beta_{1}X_{} \,+\, \varepsilon_{}, \quad =1,\ldots,n\]order determine whether\[Y_{} \,=\, \beta_{0} \,+\, \varepsilon_{}, \quad =1,\ldots,n\]appropriate model.code says build linear regression model using y dependent (response)
variable, x independent (predictor) variable, variables y x 
found within table1.1 data variable.

heading: 1.2.4 Inspecting the model
text: can obtain summary linear regression model using summary() function.information , fitted regression line equation:\[\widehat{y}_{} \,=\, 13.62 \,-\, 0.08x_{} \quad =1,\ldots,n\]
code:
summary(slr_model)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = y ~ x, data = table1.1)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -1.6789 -0.5291 -0.1221  0.7988  1.3457 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept) 13.62299    0.58146  23.429  < 2e-16 ***
## x           -0.07983    0.01052  -7.586 1.05e-07 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 0.8901 on 23 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.7144, Adjusted R-squared:  0.702 
## F-statistic: 57.54 on 1 and 23 DF,  p-value: 1.055e-07

heading: 1.2.5 Is an intercept-only model appropriate?
text:
determine whether intercept-model appropriate, need test hypotheses:\[H_{0}: \beta_{1} \,=\, 0, \quad H_{}: \beta_{1} \,\neq\, 0\]value test statistic can read summary table value -7.586 
corresponding \(p\)-value 1.05e-07. Using significance level \(\alpha = 0.05\), since
\(p\)-value less \(\alpha\), reject null hypothesis conclude 
evidence support claim \(\beta_{1}\) different zero., consider intercept-model.\(p\)-value greater \(\alpha = 0.05\) failed reject null
hypothesis? fit intercept-model?Aside: note (Intercept) row, t-value \(p\)-value correspond testing 
hypotheses:\[H_{0}: \beta_{0} \,=\, 0, \quad H_{}: \beta_{0} \,\neq\, 0\]

heading: 1.2.7 Fitting a SLR
text:
create simple linear regression model using area dependent (response) variable 
shape independent (predictor) variable.equation fitted line :\[\widehat{y}_{} \,=\, 8465 \,-\, 5855x_{}, \quad =1,\ldots,n\]Testing hypotheses:\[H_{0}: \beta_{1} \,=\, 0, \quad H_{}: \beta_{1} \,\neq\, 0\]corresponding \(p\)-value 0.215. Using significance level \(\alpha = 0.05\), since 
\(p\)-value greater 0.05, fail reject null hypothesis. , insufficient
evidence support claim \(\beta_{1}\) non-zero.Now fit intercept-model!
code:
rock_slr_model <- lm(area ~ shape, data=rock)

summary(rock_slr_model)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = area ~ shape, data = rock)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -6101.6 -1512.3   104.6  1765.3  5152.9 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)     8465       1087   7.788 6.08e-10 ***
## shape          -5855       4660  -1.256    0.215    
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 2667 on 46 degrees of freedom
## Multiple R-squared:  0.03318,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.01216 
## F-statistic: 1.579 on 1 and 46 DF,  p-value: 0.2153

heading: 1.2.8 Fitting an intercept-only model
text:
One way fitting intercept-model use lm() .dependent (response) variable remains area, right-hand side formula just
1 indicate intercept.second way fitting intercept-model take advantage fact already
built simple linear regression model (rock_slr_model) obtain intercept-model 
just need "remove" shape variable formula specification. can accomplished
using update() function.formula specification , . refers "everything already ". ,
. left ~ refers area, . right ~ refers 
1 + shape (1 usually written since linear regression models fit 
intercept default, still exists!). Therefore, code says 
rock_intercept_model "update" rock_slr_model modification 
formula now area ~ 1 + shape - shape, resulting area ~ 1. can check 
exactly wanted calling:update() function extremely useful start working multiple linear
regression models variable selection procedures later course sometimes
easier specify variables want rather ones want.output , equation fitted line :\[\widehat{y}_{} \,=\, 7187.7, \quad =1,\ldots,n\]
code:
rock_intercept_model <- lm(area ~ 1, data=rock)
rock_intercept_model <- update(rock_slr_model, formula = . ~ . - shape)
formula(rock_intercept_model)## area ~ 1
summary(rock_intercept_model)## 
## Call:
## lm(formula = area ~ 1, data = rock)
## 
## Residuals:
##     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
## -6171.7 -1882.5   299.3  1681.8  5024.3 
## 
## Coefficients:
##             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
## (Intercept)   7187.7      387.4   18.55   <2e-16 ***
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 
## Residual standard error: 2684 on 47 degrees of freedom
